G.L. c. 215, \u00a7\u00a7 3, 6.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 215, §§ 3, 6 and G.L. c. 208, § 28, as incorporated in custody and parenting matters, and under G.L. c. 209C, § 10 (as applicable to custody and parenting time for children born outside of marriage), as the child and the parties reside within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 215, §§ 3, 6 and G.L. c. 208, § 28, as incorporated in custody and parenting matters, and under G.L. c. 209C, § 10 (as applicable to custody and parenting time for children born outside of marriage), as the child and the parties reside within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 10 (as applicable t.raw_text: G.L. c. 209C, § 10 (as applicable to custody and parenting time for children born outside of marriage)
G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 10 (as applicable t.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 215, §§ 3, 6 and G.L. c. 208, § 28, as incorporated in custody and parenting matters, and under G.L. c. 209C, § 10 (as applicable to custody and parenting time for children born outside of marriage), as the child and the parties reside within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 10(b).proposition: Since entry of the Existing Custody Order on September 15, 2021, there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the welfare and best interests of Ethan, such that a modification of the Existing Custody Order is necessary and appropriate.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Since entry of the Existing Custody Order on September 15, 2021, there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the welfare and best interests of Ethan, such that a modification of the Existing Custody Order is necessary and appropriate.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a material and substantial change in circumstances after entry of an existing custody order, justifying modification. Custody of Vaughn is an appeal from an initial custody determination and addresses how courts must consider domestic violence and make explicit findings when awarding or continuing custody, not the standard for post‑judgment modification based on changed circumstances. The opinion does not discuss or apply a “material and substantial change in circumstances” test tied to a prior order’s date, so it does not support the claimed proposition.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: "Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above."

These changed circumstances directly imp.raw_text: These changed circumstances directly implicate the safety, emotional well‑being, and best interests of Ethan and render the Existing Custody Order no longer appropriate without modification.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: These changed circumstances directly implicate the safety, emotional well‑being, and best interests of Ethan and render the Existing Custody Order no longer appropriate without modification.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns whether changed circumstances affecting the children’s safety, emotional well‑being, and best interests render an existing custody order inappropriate without modification. Custody of Kali is not a modification case; the SJC expressly declines to apply or discuss the ‘substantial change in circumstances’ standard under G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and instead analyzes an initial custody determination under a pure ‘best interests’ framework. The opinion therefore does not establish or apply any rule about when changed circumstances make an existing order no longer appropriate, and does not support the cited proposition.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”}

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: These changed circumstances directly implicate the safety, emotional well‑being, and best interests of Ethan and render the Existing Custody Order no longer appropriate without modification.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The quoted concurrence in Smith v. McDonald concerns statutory interpretation of the Massachusetts paternity statute and the limits of a court’s authority to order a relocating, sole‑custody mother to return to Massachusetts. It does not discuss “changed circumstances,” nor does it hold that such circumstances affect the safety, emotional well‑being, or best interests of a child so as to render an existing custody order inappropriate. The opinion instead focuses on the mother’s right to relocate and the improper use of the Yannas ‘real advantage’ test, not on modifying a prior custody order due to new conditions.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: “Once it was established that the mother had relocated prior to an adjudication of paternity, the judge had no grounds to examine the reasons for or sincerity of the mother’s move. After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Rather, she seeks reasonable conditions and/or supervision of overnights to ensure that Ethan’s safety and best interests are protected.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a parent’s request for reasonable conditions and/or supervision of overnight visitation to protect a child’s safety and best interests. Rolde v. Rolde addresses custody, visitation amounts, and the best‑interests standard generally, but it does not discuss imposing special conditions on, or supervision of, overnights. The opinion simply upholds a reduction in the father’s visitation time; it does not provide authority for tailoring visitation with specific safety-related conditions or supervision.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt:
“We pause merely to touch upon the husband’s claim that the judge ‘cut back so severely on the amount of time that [he] may spend with his children that it now is impossible for him to maintain a meaningful relationship with them.’ There is no error.

From our above discussion of the record, it should be readily apparent that in view of the circumstances and the personalities involved the judge was justified in reducing the husband’s visitation to less than it previously had been under the temporary custody order.”

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.proposition: The pattern of reported and observed impairment and the resulting impact on Ethan’s rest, school readiness, and sense of safety constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances sufficient to warrant modification of the prior custody/parenting‑time order.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.support_reasoning: The opinion does address modification of custody and the statutory standard of a “material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties,” but it does not discuss any pattern of reported or observed impairment or impacts on a child’s rest, school readiness, or sense of safety. Instead, the only articulated basis for modification was the parents’ inability to communicate, and the court ultimately vacated the custody modification for lack of adequate best‑interest findings. Thus, this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition asserted about impairment-based changes warranting modification.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’ … The only finding contained in the modification judgment is that ‘the parties are unable to communicate with one another.’”

Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct. 215 (2002)
Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The pattern of reported and observed impairment and the resulting impact on Ethan’s rest, school readiness, and sense of safety constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances sufficient to warrant modification of the prior custody/parenting‑time order.
Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The case is about valuation of a sole proprietorship, support, and modification of alimony based on the wife’s disability and financial circumstances. It does not address custody, parenting time, children’s rest or school readiness, or a child’s sense of safety as factors in a material and substantial change in circumstances. The only modification discussion concerns financial need and income; therefore it does not support the proposition regarding impairment of a child as a basis for custody/parenting‑time modification.
Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt:
“Based upon the evidence, the findings, and the trial judge’s broad range of discretion, we must conclude that his decisions on the complaint for modification and the parties’ request for counsel fees are to stand.”

“[T]his court has conditioned modification upon a demonstrated change in circumstances after entry of the original decree… The determination of the extent and palpability of such change, however, lies in large measure within the discretion of the trial judge.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, custody and parenting‑time determinations must be governed by the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 10(a).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, custody and parenting‑time determinations must be governed by the best interests of the child.

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, custody and parenting‑time determinations must be governed by the best interests of the child.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The court explicitly interprets the Massachusetts removal statute to mean that removal decisions must be based on the best interests of the child and then applies that standard in evaluating both custody and relocation. The opinion further reiterates that the best interests of the children are always the paramount concern in these determinations, confirming that Massachusetts custody and parenting‑time decisions are governed by the child’s best interests.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that … the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.… Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).proposition: The best‑interest standard includes consideration of the child’s safety, emotional growth, happiness, and stability, as well as each parent’s capacity to provide day‑to‑day care, meet the child’s needs, and refrain from conduct that endangers or undermines the child’s well‑being.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the parental unfitness standard and the limits of state intervention in removing a child from a natural parent, rather than articulating a detailed best‑interest test listing safety, emotional growth, happiness, stability, and each parent’s caregiving capacity. It notes that parental fitness and the child’s best interests are related but does not spell out the multi‑factor best‑interest standard described in the proposition. Thus, while tangentially related to best interests, the case does not clearly establish the specific, factor‑based formulation claimed.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).relevant_excerpt: “‘State intervention in the parent-child relationship is justified only when parents appear unable to provide for their children’s care and protection.’ … In that sense, the fitness of parents and the best interests of the child are related. … ‘[T]he critical question is whether the natural parents are currently fit to further the welfare and best interests of the child.’”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The best‑interest standard includes consideration of the child’s safety, emotional growth, happiness, and stability, as well as each parent’s capacity to provide day‑to‑day care, meet the child’s needs, and refrain from conduct that endangers or undermines the child’s well‑being.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely applies the “best interests of the child” standard and emphasizes that courts must expressly consider the impact of domestic violence on the child and on the abusive parent’s parenting ability—i.e., the child’s safety and well‑being, and whether a parent’s conduct endangers the child. The facts and the court’s discussion also reflect consideration of the father’s day‑to‑day caregiving role and the child’s functioning and school performance, which relate to emotional growth, stability, and capacity to meet needs. However, the court does not provide a neat, enumerated definition of best interests including all the listed factors, so the support is inferential rather than explicit.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ … The Probate Court failed to consider the special risks to the child in awarding custody to a father who had committed acts of violence against the mother. … It is well documented that witnessing domestic violence, as well as being one of its victims, has a profound impact on children.”

Adoption of Greta, 431 Mass. 577 (2000).proposition: A parent’s misuse of alcohol or other substances during periods of responsibility for a child, especially during overnight care, presents a significant risk to the child’s physical safety and emotional security and is contrary to the child’s best interests.
Adoption of Greta, 431 Mass. 577 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on mental illness, refusal of psychotropic medication, rejection of supportive services, and failure to meet a child’s emotional and physical needs as grounds for unfitness and termination, not on parental misuse of alcohol or other substances. There is no discussion of substance abuse, intoxication during periods of responsibility, or specific risk arising from parental drinking or drug use during overnight or other care. Therefore, it does not establish or affirm the proposition about substance misuse and child safety/best interests.
Adoption of Greta, 431 Mass. 577 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “Parental unfitness…means ‘grievous shortcomings or handicaps’ that put the child’s welfare ‘much at hazard.’ … Here it was clear from the judge’s careful and comprehensive findings and his rationale for the decree that his judgment was not based simply on the handicap of the mother’s periodic psychiatric problems… but rather on a constellation of factors that pointed to termination as being in the best interests of the child.” (Adoption of Greta, 431 Mass. 577, 587-88).

Adoption of Helen, 429 Mass. 856 (1999).proposition: A parent’s misuse of alcohol or other substances during periods of responsibility for a child, especially during overnight care, presents a significant risk to the child’s physical safety and emotional security and is contrary to the child’s best interests.
Adoption of Helen, 429 Mass. 856 (1999).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the mother’s serious substance abuse problem as part of a broader pattern of parental unfitness (abandonment, failure to visit, failure to communicate, missed appointments), but it does not specifically address misuse of alcohol or drugs during periods of responsibility for the child, such as overnight care. Nor does it expressly analyze how substance use during caretaking presents a specific risk to the child’s physical safety or emotional security. The case therefore supports substance abuse as a factor in parental unfitness and best‑interests analysis, but not the more particularized proposition stated.
Adoption of Helen, 429 Mass. 856 (1999).relevant_excerpt: We conclude that the department met its burden of proving parental unfitness by clear and convincing evidence. Although some of the judge’s subsidiary findings were erroneous, the judge amply supported his conclusion that the mother is currently unfit to care for her child. The judge made fifty-nine findings that demonstrate a history of substance abuse, a pattern of late and missed appointments, failure to communicate her whereabouts to the department, and a minimal amount of communication with the child over a significant period of time.

Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).proposition: The reported exhaustion and reduced functioning Ethan displays at school following weekends with Father demonstrate that the current overnight arrangement is adversely affecting Ethan’s rest, daily functioning, and educational experience, which are central to his best interests.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns how a current overnight parenting-time arrangement affects a child’s rest, functioning, and schooling as part of a best-interests analysis. Felton v. Felton addresses modification of visitation based on a noncustodial parent’s religious instruction and holds that visitation limits require detailed proof of specific physical or emotional harm; it does not discuss overnights, rest, school functioning, or educational impact. While Felton generally stresses the need for concrete evidence of harm to the child, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about post-weekend exhaustion and reduced school functioning from overnight visits.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “The more striking weakness is a failure of proof about Deborah’s physical and emotional condition or about any causal connections between her visits with her father and that condition… General testimony by Diane that the child was upset or confused… will not suffice… The decisions hold such an infirmity to be fatal to an action seeking to limit materially or to cancel visitation rights… Thus there is clear error, for lack of foundation in the record, in the judge’s findings of a ‘deleterious effect’ on the children… by reason of the father’s religious instruction or practice.”

R.H. v. B.F., 39 Mass. App. Ct. 29 (1995.raw_text: R.H. v. B.F., 39 Mass. App. Ct. 29 (1995)
R.H. v. B.F., 39 Mass. App. Ct. 29 (1995.proposition: Parenting time may be conditioned or structured, including through supervision or specific restrictions, when necessary to protect a child.
R.H. v. B.F., 39 Mass. App. Ct. 29 (1995.support_reasoning: The case is primarily about deficiencies in findings on domestic violence in a custody determination, but in doing so it recognizes that where there is credible evidence of abuse, courts must consider the impact on the child and, if access is allowed, "make arrangements to protect" family members. The court also favorably cites expert testimony proposing supervised visitation if counseling conditions are not met. While the holding focuses on remand for new custody findings, its reasoning affirms that parenting time may be structured or conditioned (including supervision) to protect the child in the context of domestic violence.
R.H. v. B.F., 39 Mass. App. Ct. 29 (1995.relevant_excerpt: “The legislature and/or appellate courts should make it clear that abuse of any family member affects other family members and must be considered in determining the best interests of the child in connection with any order concerning custody. If access to the child is allowed, judges should be directed to make arrangements to protect any family member from further abuse.” … The psychologist encouraged unsupervised visitation… provided that the mother, the father, and the child were in counseling. If there were no counseling, ‘I think we’re looking more at some sort of supervised visitation.’”}

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Parenting time may be conditioned or structured, including through supervision or specific restrictions, when necessary to protect a child.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the standards for awarding custody—emphasizing that decisions must be based on the child’s welfare and that custody is not to be used to punish a parent. It does not discuss parenting time/visitation, supervision, or specific restrictions on contact as protective measures. Because the case neither addresses nor authorizes structuring or conditioning parenting time, it does not support the claimed proposition.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… The award of custody to one parent is not a device to be used by judges to discipline the other parent for his or her ‘shortcomings.’ … ‘Custody is not a prize . . . .’”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: To the extent the Existing Custody Order contemplates unsupervised overnight parenting time with Father without conditions regarding alcohol or substance use, that order is no longer in Ethan’s best interests in light of the current circumstances and should be modified accordingly.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 10.proposition: To the extent the Existing Custody Order contemplates unsupervised overnight parenting time with Father without conditions regarding alcohol or substance use, that order is no longer in Ethan’s best interests in light of the current circumstances and should be modified accordingly.
